Personalized Federated Learning via Convex Clustering

Aleksandar Armacki Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA
Email: {aarmacki, soummyak}@andrew.cmu.edu Dragana Bajovic Faculty of Technical Sciences, University of Novi Sad, Novi Sad, Serbia
Email: dbajovic@uns.ac.rs Dusan Jakovetic Faculty of Sciences, University of Novi Sad, Novi Sad, Serbia
Email: dusan.jakovetic@dmi.uns.ac.rs Soummya Kar Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA
Email: {aarmacki, soummyak}@andrew.cmu.edu
Abstract

We propose a parametric family of algorithms for personalized federated learning with locally convex user costs. The proposed framework is based on a generalization of convex clustering in which the differences between different users‚Äô models are penalized via a sum-of-norms penalty, weighted by a penalty parameter¬†ŒªùúÜ\lambda. The proposed approach enables ‚Äúautomatic‚Äù model clustering, without prior knowledge of the hidden cluster structure, nor the number of clusters. Analytical bounds on the weight parameter, that lead to simultaneous personalization, generalization and automatic model clustering are provided. The solution to the formulated problem enables personalization, by providing different models across different clusters, and generalization, by providing models different than the per-user models computed in isolation. We then provide an efficient algorithm based on the Parallel Direction Method of Multipliers (PDMM) to solve the proposed formulation in a federated server-users setting. Numerical experiments corroborate our findings. As an interesting byproduct, our results provide several generalizations to convex clustering.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a paradigm in which many users collaborate, with the goal of learning a joint model [1]. Each user has a local dataset, with private and possibly sensitive data. The data distribution across users is typically highly heterogeneous. ‚Ä†‚Ä†The work of D. Bajovic is supported by the European Union‚Äôs Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation program under grant agreement No 957337. The work of A. Armacki and S. Kar was partially supported by the National Science Foundation under grant CNS-1837607. This paper reflects only the authors‚Äô views and the European Commission cannot be held responsible for any use which may be made of the information contained therein.

A federated learning system can have a huge amount of users, wherein each user contributes with a proportionally small local dataset. Therefore, the federation provides users with the benefit of training on the joint data, effectively offering broader knowledge and better generalization. However, due to the highly heterogeneous nature of the data, it is nontrivial to design a FL system where individual users achieve better performance though the federation when compared with models trained on their own local data. In fact, the authors in¬†[2] show that in many tasks, users may actually not benefit from participating in federated learning. The globally trained model underperforms on their local data, compared to the model solely trained on the local data. Moreover, applying privacy preserving techniques further deteriorates the performance. On the other hand, users with very small datasets suffer from overfitting and poor generalization of models trained only on their local data.

To amend these problems and reap the benefits of both worlds ‚Äì the abundance of data and better learning that the federation offers, as well as adapting the models to perform well on the local data, personalized federated learning is introduced. Unlike the standard federated learning, the goal of personalized federated learning is to learn multiple models. In particular, let NùëÅN be the number of participating users, with f:‚Ñùd‚Ü¶‚Ñù:ùëìmaps-tosuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñùf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\mapsto\mathbb{R} a given cost function. Then, the goal of standard FL is to solve

arg‚Äãminx‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°Fglobal‚Äã(x)=1N‚Äã‚àëi=1Nfi‚Äã(x),subscriptargminùë•superscript‚Ñùùëësubscriptùêπglobalùë•1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùëìùëñùë•\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F_{\text{global}}(x)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x), (1)

where fi‚Äã(x)subscriptùëìùëñùë•f_{i}(x) is the cost function fùëìf evaluated on the local dataset of the iùëñi-th user. Contrary to this approach, the (broad) goal of personalized FL is to learn NùëÅN models, by solving

arg‚Äãminx1,‚Ä¶,xN‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°Flocal‚Äã(x1,‚Ä¶,xN)=1N‚Äã‚àëi=1Nfi‚Äã(xi),subscriptargminsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëÅsuperscript‚Ñùùëësubscriptùêπlocalsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëÅ1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{x_{1},\ldots,x_{N}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F_{\text{local}}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{N})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i}), (2)

subject to appropriately defined constraints. Depending on the constraints imposed and the approach taken to solving (2), the literature on personalized FL adopts different approaches to personalization, including multi-task learning [3], [4], fine-tuning [5], [6], knowledge distillation [7], [8], [9], [10] and clustering-based approaches [11], [12], [13].

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to personalized federated learning that enables simultaneous personalization, generalization, and model clustering. The approach is based on the following novel personalized FL (convex problem) formulation:

arg‚Äãminx1,‚Ä¶,xN‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°F‚Äã(x1,‚Ä¶,xN)=1N‚Äã‚àëi=1Nfi‚Äã(xi)+Œª‚Äã‚àëj‚â†i‚Äñxi‚àíxj‚Äñ,subscriptargminsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëÅsuperscript‚Ñùùëëùêπsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëÅ1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùúÜsubscriptùëóùëñnormsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëó\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{x_{1},\ldots,x_{N}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F(x_{1},\ldots,x_{N})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i})+\lambda\sum_{j\neq i}\|x_{i}-x_{j}\|, (3)

where Œª>0ùúÜ0\lambda>0 is a penalty parameter, and ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•\|\cdot\| stands for the Euclidean norm. Compared with¬†(2), the formulation¬†(3) has a regularization term controlled with¬†Œª>0ùúÜ0\lambda>0, that penalizes the differences between the local nodes‚Äô solutions via a sum-of-norms penalty.

Formulation¬†(3) may be seen as a generalization of convex clustering, e.g.,¬†[14], where, instead of the (quadratic) distance functions, which penalize the departure from a local data point, we use arbitrary convex local losses.

Problem¬†(3) is also related with the personalized FL formulation in¬†[15], which, instead of the sum of norms of pairwise distances uses the sum of squared norms of distances of local solutions to their average. As we show in the paper, although the two formulations are resembling, the solution structures of the two formulations are qualitatively very different.

Specifically, as we show in the paper, the solution to¬†(3) has several interesting properties, which, to the best of our knowledge, are not (jointly) exhibited with any of the previous personalized FL formulations. Namely, a solution to¬†(3) has a clustered structure: depending on the penalty parameter ŒªùúÜ\lambda and similarity of the local functions, local solutions xi‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜx_{i}^{\star} of (3) are equal across certain users‚Äô groups (clusters). The number of groups (clusters) KùêæK is automatically determined as part of the solution. To further illustrate benefits of this feature, suppose that the users exhibit an (unknown) clustered structure such that each user‚Äôs data within a cluster comes from the same distribution, while the distributions that correspond to different clusters are mutually different. If the different clusters‚Äô distributions are sufficiently far apart, the proposed method (3) uncovers the unknown cluster structure and hence allocates the same models to all users within the same cluster. This allows within-cluster generalization, i.e., users to effectively enlarge their training data by harnessing data of all users from the same cluster. In addition, depending on the distance between the different clusters‚Äô distributions, the method (3) allows for a controlled across-clusters generalization; intuitively, it allows a user to harness data from another clusters‚Äô distribution, but with a different (reduced) ‚Äùweight‚Äù when compared to within-cluster data. If, at an extreme, the difference between different clusters‚Äô distributions is negligible (but this information is unknown), then users should clearly use the global model (1). This is again captured by (3), because (as shown in the paper) it matches (1) for ŒªùúÜ\lambda above a threshold.

In summary, our contributions are the following: First, we propose a novel formulation for personalized federated learning¬†(3), the solution of which has a clustering structure while at the same time preserving generalization abilities.

Second, we provide a condition on the penalty parameter ŒªùúÜ\lambda, with theoretical guarantees, for discovering the ‚Äúhidden structure‚Äù underlying the models; this condition is expressed in terms of the well-established diversity of the local functions, hence making a strong connection and justifying analytically the use of this quantity.

Third, the proposed solution ‚Äùautomatically‚Äù determines the number of models KùêæK, i.e., KùêæK need not be known in advance.

Fourth, we provide an efficient algorithm to solve the novel personalized learning formulation¬†(3) in a federated server-client setting that is based upon the Parallel Direction Method of Multipliers (PDMM)¬†[16].

Finally, we demonstrate by simulation examples, on a supervized binary classification problem, that the proposed solution exhibits 1)1) generalization, i.e., improves testing accuracy with respect to the users models trained in isolation; 2)2) personalization, i.e., improves testing accuracy with respect to the global FL model (1); and 3)3) achieves a comparable (or better) generalization and personalization (in the sense of 1)1) and 2)2)) than [4], while at the same time uncovering cluster structure, hence reducing the number of distinct models from NùëÅN to KùêæK.

With respect to existing personalized FL approaches discussed above, the works [11, 12, 13, 10] also account for users‚Äô clustering in a certain way, but very differently from our approach. Most notably, existing approaches aim to uncover ‚Äúcluster identities‚Äù first and subsequently provide loss minimizations across cluster groups in isolation from other groups. This within-clusters isolation may reduce overall generalization ability of the models. In contrast, the proposed approach allows also for across-clusters generalization that is further controlled by the penalty parameter¬†ŒªùúÜ\lambda. It is worth noting that reference [17] introduces formulation similar to (3), but in a different context of distributed consensus optimization. Most importantly, they are only concerned with the question when (3) matches (1), i.e., when (3) leads to a global consensus across local models; they are not concerned, nor they study personalization (clustering) abilities of (3).

Our results are also of direct interest to convex clustering, e.g.,¬†[14], as they provide recovery guarantees for generalized convex clustering, when the squared quadratic loss fi‚Äã(x):=‚Äñxi‚àíai‚Äñ2assignsubscriptùëìùëñùë•superscriptnormsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëéùëñ2f_{i}(x):=\|x_{i}-a_{i}\|^{2} per data point¬†ai‚àà‚Ñùdsubscriptùëéùëñsuperscript‚Ñùùëëa_{i}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d} is replaced with an arbitrary differentiable convex loss, e.g., the Huber loss.

Paper organization. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section II describes the problem of interest and outlines the assumptions used in the analysis. Section III presents the recovery guarantees of the method. Section IV outlines an efficient algorithm for solving the proposed problem in the federated setting. Section V presents numerical experiments, and Section VI concludes the paper. The next paragraph introduces the notation used throughout the paper.

II Problem formulation

Consider a collection of NùëÅN users, i=1,‚Ä¶,Nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi=1,\ldots,N, that participate in a federated learning activity. Each user iùëñi holds a function fi:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:subscriptùëìùëñ‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñùf_{i}:\,{\mathbb{R}}^{d}\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}}. Function fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} may correspond, e.g., to an empirical loss with respect to the local data set available at user¬†iùëñi. We make the following assumptions throughout the paper.

Assumption 1.

For each i=1,‚Ä¶,Nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi=1,\ldots,N, function fi:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:subscriptùëìùëñ‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñùf_{i}:\,{\mathbb{R}}^{d}\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}} is convex and coercive, i.e., fi‚Äã(x)‚Üí+‚àû‚Üísubscriptùëìùëñùë•f_{i}(x)\rightarrow+\infty whenever ‚Äñx‚Äñ‚Üí+‚àû‚Üínormùë•\|x\|\rightarrow+\infty.

Assumption 2.

For each i=1,‚Ä¶,Nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi=1,\ldots,N, function fi:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:subscriptùëìùëñ‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñùf_{i}:\,{\mathbb{R}}^{d}\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}} has Lipschitz continuous gradients, i.e. the following holds

‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(x)‚àí‚àáfi‚Äã(y)‚Äñ‚â§L‚Äã‚Äñx‚àíy‚Äñ,for‚Äãall‚Äãx,y‚àà‚Ñùd.formulae-sequencenorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë•‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë¶ùêønormùë•ùë¶forallùë•ùë¶superscript‚Ñùùëë\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{i}(y)\|\leq L\|x-y\|,\>\mathrm{for\,all\,}\>x,y\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}.

Note that, under the above assumptions, problems¬†(1) and¬†(3) are solvable. We denote by y‚ãÜ‚àà‚Ñùdsuperscriptùë¶‚ãÜsuperscript‚Ñùùëëy^{\star}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d} a solution to¬†(1) and by {xi‚ãÜ}superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜ\{x_{i}^{\star}\}, i=1,‚Ä¶,Nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi=1,\ldots,N, xi‚ãÜ‚àà‚Ñùdsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜsuperscript‚Ñùùëëx_{i}^{\star}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, a solution to¬†(3).

There are many machine learning models that satisfy Assumptions¬†1 and¬†2, such as supervized binary classification problems studied in Section V.

The high-level goal in personalized federated learning is that each user iùëñi finds a local model, say xi‚àô‚àà‚Ñùdsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚àôsuperscript‚Ñùùëëx_{i}^{\bullet}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, that performs well on the local data (i.e., the value fi‚Äã(xi‚àô)subscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚àôf_{i}(x_{i}^{\bullet}) is low), but that also exhibits a generalization ability with respect to data available at other users¬†j‚â†iùëóùëñj\neq i. In addition, a desirable feature of personalized federated learning is that the users are able to classify other users into two categories. The first category corresponds to those users j‚àà{1,2,‚Ä¶,N}ùëó12‚Ä¶ùëÅj\in\{1,2,\ldots,N\} that have similar data (similar fjsubscriptùëìùëóf_{j}‚Äôs) to their own; the second category corresponds to those users whose local data is ‚Äúsufficiently different‚Äù from theirs. With this classification in place, each user iùëñi can fully harness the data from ‚Äúsimilar users‚Äù for an improved personalization while avoiding overfitting; e.g., when user¬†iùëñi has a very few data points of its own, it effectively enlarges its data set while preserving personalization. On the other hand, the data from ‚Äúsufficiently different users‚Äù should still be harnessed in a controlled way to further improve generalization abilities.

To account for the effects above, we provide a novel personalized learning formulation, where each user iùëñi wants to obtain the local model xi‚ãÜ‚àà‚Ñùdsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜsuperscript‚Ñùùëëx_{i}^{\star}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d} such that x‚ãÜ:=((x1‚ãÜ)‚ä§,‚Ä¶,(xN‚ãÜ)‚ä§)‚ä§‚àà‚ÑùN‚Äãdassignsuperscriptùë•‚ãÜsuperscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùë•1‚ãÜtop‚Ä¶superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëÅ‚ãÜtoptopsuperscript‚ÑùùëÅùëëx^{\star}:=((x_{1}^{\star})^{\top},\ldots,(x_{N}^{\star})^{\top})^{\top}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{N\,d} is a minimizer of¬†(3), where Œª>0ùúÜ0\lambda>0 is a tuning parameter. Intuitively, the term ‚àëi=1Nfi‚Äã(xi)superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i}) forces the local models xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}‚Äôs to behave well with respect to local costs fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i}‚Äôs; the term Œª‚Äã‚àëj‚â†i‚Äñxi‚àíxj‚ÄñùúÜsubscriptùëóùëñnormsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëó\lambda\,\sum_{j\neq i}\|x_{i}-x_{j}\| makes the local models be mutually close, hence enabling generalization. The penalization term ‚àëj‚â†i‚Äñxi‚àíxj‚Äñsubscriptùëóùëñnormsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëó\sum_{j\neq i}\|x_{i}-x_{j}\| is known to enforce sparsity in other contexts, in the sense that it forces many of the xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}‚Äôs to be mutually equal at a solution of (3).

It is interesting to compare our novel formulation (3) with the personalized federated learning formulation in [4]:

arg‚Äãminx1,‚Ä¶,xN‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°1N‚Äã‚àëi=1Nfi‚Äã(xi)+Œ≥‚Äã‚àëj‚â†i‚Äñxi‚àíxj‚Äñ2,subscriptargminsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëÅsuperscript‚Ñùùëë1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùõæsubscriptùëóùëñsuperscriptnormsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëó2\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{x_{1},\ldots,x_{N}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i})+\gamma\sum_{j\neq i}\|x_{i}-x_{j}\|^{2}, (4)

where Œ≥>0ùõæ0\gamma>0 is a penalty parameter.

The difference of (4) with respect to (3) is that, in (4), the differences of local models xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} and xjsubscriptùë•ùëóx_{j} are penalized via the squared Euclidean norm, while with our formulation, the 2-norm appears without squares. There are several important implications of this difference with respect to the resulting personalized learning models. Most importantly, in contrast with (3), formulation (4) in general does not lead to model clustering for any Œª>0ùúÜ0\lambda>0. In addition, as a side comment, the solutions to (1) and (4) are in general mutually different for any Œª>0ùúÜ0\lambda>0 (in the sense that the solution {yi‚ãÜ}superscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëñ‚ãÜ\{y_{i}^{\star}\} to (4) does not obey yi‚ãÜ=yj‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëñ‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëó‚ãÜy_{i}^{\star}=y_{j}^{\star}, for all i,jùëñùëói,j, irrespective of the choice of ŒªùúÜ\lambda). In contrast, with (3), we recover global model learning as in (1) for Œª>Œª^ùúÜ^ùúÜ\lambda>\widehat{\lambda}‚Ä†‚Ä†This can be easily seen based on Theorem 1 in [17]..

We also connect (3) with convex clustering. Convex clustering, e.g.¬†[14], is an appealing method to cluster NùëÅN data points ai‚àà‚Ñùdsubscriptùëéùëñsuperscript‚Ñùùëëa_{i}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, i=1,‚Ä¶,Nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi=1,\ldots,N. The method corresponds to solving problem (3) with fi‚Äã(x)=12‚Äã‚Äñx‚àíai‚Äñ2subscriptùëìùëñùë•12superscriptnormùë•subscriptùëéùëñ2f_{i}(x)=\frac{1}{2}\|x-a_{i}\|^{2}. Intuitively, to each data point iùëñi, we associate a candidate cluster center xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}, and then we enforce a (soft) constraint that many xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}‚Äôs should be mutually equal. There are several efficient algorithms and cluster recovery guarantees results available for convex clustering, but only when fi‚Äã(x)=12‚Äã‚Äñx‚àíai‚Äñ2subscriptùëìùëñùë•12superscriptnormùë•subscriptùëéùëñ2f_{i}(x)=\frac{1}{2}\|x-a_{i}\|^{2}. Our results make a direct generalization of convex clustering to other loss metrics, e.g., the ‚Äúdistance‚Äù of a candidate cluster xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} from data point aisubscriptùëéùëña_{i} may be measured through the Huber loss.

III Theoretical guarantees for optimal cluster recovery

In this section, we state and prove our main results on characterization of solutions to¬†(3).

We start by defining the following auxiliary optimization problem associated to a certain (predefined) partition of users C1,‚Ä¶,CKsubscriptùê∂1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∂ùêæC_{1},\ldots,C_{K}, ‚à™k=1KCk=[N]superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùê∂ùëòdelimited-[]ùëÅ\cup_{k=1}^{K}C_{k}=[N] and Ck‚à©Cj=‚àÖsubscriptùê∂ùëòsubscriptùê∂ùëóC_{k}\cap C_{j}=\emptyset:

arg‚Äãminw1,‚Ä¶,wN‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°1N‚Äã‚àëk=1Knk‚Äãgk‚Äã(wk)+Œª‚Äã‚àël‚â†knk‚Äãnl‚Äã‚Äñwk‚àíwl‚Äñ,subscriptargminsubscriptùë§1‚Ä¶subscriptùë§ùëÅsuperscript‚Ñùùëë1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëõùëòsubscriptùëîùëòsubscriptùë§ùëòùúÜsubscriptùëôùëòsubscriptùëõùëòsubscriptùëõùëônormsubscriptùë§ùëòsubscriptùë§ùëô\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{w_{1},\ldots,w_{N}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=1}^{K}n_{k}g_{k}(w_{k})+\lambda\sum_{l\neq k}n_{k}n_{l}\|w_{k}-w_{l}\|, (5)

Note that problem¬†(5) is solvable by Assumption¬†1.

Theorem 1.

Consider problem¬†(3). Assume that, for some node partition C1,C2,‚Ä¶,CKsubscriptùê∂1subscriptùê∂2‚Ä¶subscriptùê∂ùêæC_{1},C_{2},\ldots,C_{K}, and parameter ŒªùúÜ\lambda, there holds

(6)

Then, {xi‚ãÜ}superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜ\{x_{i}^{\star}\}, i=1,‚Ä¶,Nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi=1,\ldots,N, is a solution of¬†(3).

Remark 1.

Note that Theorem¬†1 guarantees that at least one solution of¬†(3) exhibits the clustered structure with respect to partition¬†C1,‚Ä¶,CKsubscriptùê∂1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∂ùêæC_{1},\ldots,C_{K}, while it does not preclude a scenario that there might be another solution of¬†(3) that may not exhibit this cluster structure. However, when each of the fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i}‚Äôs is in addition assumed to be strictly convex, then {xi‚ãÜ}superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜ\{x_{i}^{\star}\} is unique, and it necessarily has the clustered structure.

We next prove Theorem¬†1.

Theorem 1 guarantees the existence of a solution of (3) that exhibits the desired clustering structure. However, if the parameter ŒªùúÜ\lambda is chosen too large, it can actually coarsen the clustering structure C1,‚Ä¶,CKsubscriptùê∂1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∂ùêæC_{1},\ldots,C_{K} and provide a solution with 1‚â§M<K1ùëÄùêæ1\leq M<K groups (clusters). Theorem 2.

Consider problem¬†(5). If for some node partition C1,C2,‚Ä¶,CKsubscriptùê∂1subscriptùê∂2‚Ä¶subscriptùê∂ùêæC_{1},C_{2},\ldots,C_{K} and parameter Œª>0ùúÜ0\lambda>0 there holds

then for each k,l‚àà[K],k‚â†lformulae-sequenceùëòùëôdelimited-[]ùêæùëòùëôk,l\in[K],k\neq l, we have wk‚ãÜ‚â†wl‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëò‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëô‚ãÜw_{k}^{\star}\neq w_{l}^{\star}, where wk‚ãÜ=wk‚ãÜ‚Äã(Œª)superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëò‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëò‚ãÜùúÜw_{k}^{\star}=w_{k}^{\star}(\lambda), k=1,‚Ä¶,Kùëò1‚Ä¶ùêæk=1,\ldots,K, is a solution to¬†(5), defined for the same partition C1,‚Ä¶,CKsubscriptùê∂1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∂ùêæC_{1},\ldots,C_{K}, that verifies¬†(15).

We note that in practice, the bounds (6) and (15) might not be easy to obtain, as wk‚ãÜsubscriptsuperscriptùë§‚ãÜùëòw^{\star}_{k}‚Äôs depend on ŒªùúÜ\lambda. In Appendix A we provide several considerations regarding selection of the penalty parameter ŒªùúÜ\lambda in (3), in practice.

We next prove Theorem¬†2.

Proof.

Denote by sk=Œª‚Äã‚àël‚â†krk‚Äãl‚àósubscriptùë†ùëòùúÜsubscriptùëôùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùëüùëòùëôs_{k}=\lambda\sum_{l\neq k}r^{*}_{kl}. From¬†(7), we have

‚Äñsl‚àísk‚Äñnormsubscriptùë†ùëôsubscriptùë†ùëò\displaystyle\|s_{l}-s_{k}\| =‚Äñ‚àágk‚Äã(wk‚àó)‚àí‚àágl‚Äã(wl‚àó)‚Äñabsentnorm‚àásubscriptùëîùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëò‚àásubscriptùëîùëôsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëô\displaystyle=\|\nabla g_{k}(w^{*}_{k})-\nabla g_{l}(w^{*}_{l})\|
‚â§‚Äñ‚àágk‚Äã(wk‚àó)‚àígl‚Äã(wk‚àó)‚Äñ+‚Äñ‚àágl‚Äã(wk‚àó)‚àí‚àágl‚Äã(wl‚àó)‚Äñabsentnorm‚àásubscriptùëîùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëòsubscriptùëîùëôsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëònorm‚àásubscriptùëîùëôsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëò‚àásubscriptùëîùëôsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëô\displaystyle\leq\|\nabla g_{k}(w^{*}_{k})-g_{l}(w^{*}_{k})\|+\|\nabla g_{l}(w^{*}_{k})-\nabla g_{l}(w^{*}_{l})\|
‚â§‚Äñ‚àágk‚Äã(wk‚àó)‚àígl‚Äã(wk‚àó)‚Äñ+L‚Äã‚Äñwk‚àó‚àíwl‚àó‚Äñ,absentnorm‚àásubscriptùëîùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëòsubscriptùëîùëôsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëòùêønormsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëô\displaystyle\leq\|\nabla g_{k}(w^{*}_{k})-g_{l}(w^{*}_{k})\|+L\|w^{*}_{k}-w^{*}_{l}\|,

‚Äñwk‚àó‚àíwl‚àó‚Äñ‚â•1L‚Äã‚Äñ‚àágk‚Äã(wk‚àó)‚àígl‚Äã(wk‚àó)‚Äñ‚àí1L‚Äã(‚Äñsl‚Äñ+‚Äñsk‚Äñ).normsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëô1ùêønorm‚àásubscriptùëîùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëòsubscriptùëîùëôsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëò1ùêønormsubscriptùë†ùëônormsubscriptùë†ùëò\|w^{*}_{k}-w^{*}_{l}\|\geq\frac{1}{L}\|\nabla g_{k}(w^{*}_{k})-g_{l}(w^{*}_{k})\|-\frac{1}{L}(\|s_{l}\|+\|s_{k}\|).

Next, note that

‚Äñsk‚Äñ‚â§Œª‚Äã‚àël‚â†knl‚Äã‚Äñrk‚Äãl‚àó‚Äñ‚â§Œª‚Äã‚àël‚â†knl.normsubscriptùë†ùëòùúÜsubscriptùëôùëòsubscriptùëõùëônormsubscriptsuperscriptùëüùëòùëôùúÜsubscriptùëôùëòsubscriptùëõùëô\|s_{k}\|\leq\lambda\sum_{l\neq k}n_{l}\|r^{*}_{kl}\|\leq\lambda\sum_{l\neq k}n_{l}.

It can be readily checked that the choice of ŒªùúÜ\lambda satisfying¬†(15) results in

hence showing the claim. ‚àé

IV Algorithm for personalized federated learning

In this section, we introduce an algorithm to solve (3) in a federated server-users setting. The algorithm is adapted from the parallel direction method of multipliers (PDMM) in¬†[16].

We start by reformulating problem (3) as follows:

min‚Äã‚àëi=1Nfi‚Äã(xi)+Œª‚Äã‚àëj‚â†i‚Äñzi‚Äãj‚Äñminsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùúÜsubscriptùëóùëñnormsubscriptùëßùëñùëó\displaystyle\mathrm{min}\,\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i})+\lambda\sum_{j\neq i}\|z_{ij}\|
s.t.xi‚àíxj=zi‚Äãj,i‚â†j.formulae-sequencestformulae-sequencesubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëósubscriptùëßùëñùëóùëñùëó\displaystyle\mathrm{s.t.}\,\,x_{i}-x_{j}=z_{ij},\,\,i\neq j.

That is, each of the N‚Äã(N‚àí1)ùëÅùëÅ1N(N-1) terms ‚Äñxi‚àíxj‚Äñnormsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëó\|x_{i}-x_{j}\| in (3) are replaced with ‚Äñzi‚Äãj‚Äñnormsubscriptùëßùëñùëó\|z_{ij}\|, where zi‚Äãj‚àà‚Ñùdsubscriptùëßùëñùëósuperscript‚Ñùùëëz_{ij}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d} is an auxiliary (primal) variable. Then, for equivalence of (3) and (IV), we add for each ordered pair (i,j)ùëñùëó(i,j), i‚â†jùëñùëói\neq j, the constraint xi‚àíxj=zi‚Äãjsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëósubscriptùëßùëñùëóx_{i}-x_{j}=z_{ij}. where {xi}subscriptùë•ùëñ\{x_{i}\}, i=1,‚Ä¶,Nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi=1,\ldots,N, and {zi‚Äãj}subscriptùëßùëñùëó\{z_{ij}\}, i=1,‚Ä¶,Nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi=1,\ldots,N, j=1,‚Ä¶,Nùëó1‚Ä¶ùëÅj=1,\ldots,N, i‚â†jùëñùëói\neq j, are the primal variables, and {Œºi‚Äãj}subscriptùúáùëñùëó\{\mu_{ij}\}, i=1,‚Ä¶,Nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi=1,\ldots,N, j=1,‚Ä¶,Nùëó1‚Ä¶ùëÅj=1,\ldots,N, i‚â†jùëñùëói\neq j, are the dual variables, and œÅ>0ùúå0\rho>0 is a penalty parameter.‚Ä†‚Ä†It is possible to halve the number of constraints in (IV) by imposing the constraint xi‚àíxj=zi‚Äãjsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëósubscriptùëßùëñùëóx_{i}-x_{j}=z_{ij} only for i<jùëñùëói<j. This approach reduces the number of variables at the cost of additional coordination of users on the server‚Äôs side. We present here the approach with the larger number of variables and less coordination required. Abstracting details, PDMM proceeds as follows. First, it updates at each iteration t=0,1,‚Ä¶ùë°01‚Ä¶t=0,1,\ldots, a randomly selected subset of primal variables {xi,zi‚Äãj}subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëßùëñùëó\{x_{i},z_{ij}\} by minimizing a surrogate of LùêøL with the rest of primal and dual variables fixed. Then, a randomly selected subset of dual variables {Œºi‚Äãj}subscriptùúáùëñùëó\{\mu_{ij}\} is updated, while also bookkeeping a set of auxiliary dual variables {Œº^i‚Äãj}subscript^ùúáùëñùëó\{\widehat{\mu}_{ij}\}. See equations (29)‚Äì(31) in [19] for a detailed definition of the generic PDMM.

Here, we apply and adapt PDMM to solve (IV), and hence, solve (3), in the federated server-users setting. To facilitate presentation of the algorithm, we enumerate all primal variables xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}‚Äôs and zi‚Äãjsubscriptùëßùëñùëóz_{ij}‚Äôs through a common index set ùíÆPsubscriptùíÆùëÉ\mathcal{S}_{P} with N2superscriptùëÅ2N^{2} elements, such that the iùëñi-th element of ùíÆPsubscriptùíÆùëÉ\mathcal{S}_{P}, i=1,‚Ä¶,Nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi=1,\ldots,N, corresponds to xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}, and the remaining N‚Äã(N‚àí1)ùëÅùëÅ1N(N-1) subsequent elements correspond to zi‚Äãjsubscriptùëßùëñùëóz_{ij}‚Äôs, where the ordered pairs ‚Ñì‚àº(i,j)similar-to‚Ñìùëñùëó\ell\sim(i,j) are positioned lexicographically in ùíÆPsubscriptùíÆùëÉ\mathcal{S}_{P}. The PDMM-based personalized FL method is shown in Algorithm¬†1.

With Algorithm¬†1‚Äôs initialization, we can set the zi‚Äãj(0)superscriptsubscriptùëßùëñùëó0z_{ij}^{(0)}‚Äôs, Œºi‚Äãj(0)superscriptsubscriptùúáùëñùëó0\mu_{ij}^{(0)}‚Äôs, and and Œº^i‚Äãj(0)superscriptsubscript^ùúáùëñùëó0\widehat{\mu}_{ij}^{(0)}‚Äôs arbitrarily. With Algorithm¬†1, the server maintains and updates the N‚Äã(N‚àí1)ùëÅùëÅ1N(N-1) d√ó1ùëë1d\times 1-sized dual variables Œºi‚Äãj(t+1)superscriptsubscriptùúáùëñùëóùë°1\mu_{ij}^{(t+1)}, i,j=1,‚Ä¶,Nformulae-sequenceùëñùëó1‚Ä¶ùëÅi,j=1,\ldots,N, i‚â†jùëñùëói\neq j. With Algorithm¬†1, communication from users to the server (‚Äúuplink‚Äù) takes place at steps (S5) and (S6). Note that, at each tùë°t, during steps (S5) and (S6), the server receives exactly SPsubscriptùëÜùëÉS_{P} d√ó1ùëë1d\times 1-sized (real vectors) messages. Here, SPsubscriptùëÜùëÉS_{P} is the design parameter that can be taken to be much smaller than NùëÅN, hence the uplink communication does not incur high overhead. Communication from the server to users (‚Äúdownlink‚Äù) takes place at steps (S7) and (S10). At step (S7), the server brodcasts SDsubscriptùëÜùê∑S_{D} d√ó1ùëë1d\times 1-sized messages. (Specifically, variable Œºi‚Äãj(t+1)superscriptsubscriptùúáùëñùëóùë°1\mu_{ij}^{(t+1)} is sent to user iùëñi, for ‚Ñì‚àº(i,j)similar-to‚Ñìùëñùëó\ell\sim(i,j), ‚Ñì‚ààùíÆD(t)‚ÑìsuperscriptsubscriptùíÆùê∑ùë°\ell\in{\mathcal{S}}_{D}^{(t)}.) Quantity SDsubscriptùëÜùê∑S_{D} is also a design parameter that can be set to be much smaller than NùëÅN; hence, the downlink communication does not incur a significant communication overhead.

V Numerical results

We now present numerical simulations. In the first set of experiments, we evaluate the cluster recovery abilities, as well as personalization and generalization abilities of the proposed formulation (3) and compare it with alternatives.

We now describe the first set of experiments. We consider a supervized binary classification problem. The generated data contains K=3ùêæ3K=3 clusters. For each cluster, for each given label/class (¬±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1), the data comes from a uniform distribution over an ellipse in ‚Ñù2superscript‚Ñù2\mathbb{R}^{2}. The two ellipses that correspond to different classes for a given cluster overlap, so that the data in each cluster is not linearly separable. We generate 200 (training) data points from the distributions from each cluster, 100 points per class. Then, we associate to each cluster 20 FL users. Each FL user samples 10 data points out of the 200 data points available in its cluster. Hence, the data for all users within a cluster comes from the same distribution. Figure 1 illustrates the data, where different colors corresponds to different clusters, while the dashed lines represent optimal separators for each cluster, computed using the squared Hinge loss, i.e. the separators that minimize the squared Hinge loss over the full training data, for each cluster. The squared Hinge loss is used throughout the simulations, as the local loss function of each user iùëñi, and is given by

fi(x)=c‚Äã‚Äñw‚Äñ22+1m‚àëj=1mmax{0,1‚àí‚Ñìi‚Äãj(‚ü®w,ai‚Äãj‚ü©‚àíb)}2,f_{i}(x)=\frac{c\|w\|^{2}}{2}+\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}\max\big{\{}0,1-\ell_{ij}(\langle w,a_{ij}\rangle-b)\big{\}}^{2},

where mùëöm represents the number of (local) data points, (ai‚Äãj,‚Ñìi‚Äãj)j=1msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëéùëñùëósubscript‚Ñìùëñùëóùëó1ùëö(a_{ij},\ell_{ij})_{j=1}^{m}, represent the data points and class labels at user iùëñi, c>0ùëê0c>0 is a penalty parameter that controls the regularization, while x=[w,b]‚àà‚Ñùd+1,d=2formulae-sequenceùë•matrixùë§ùëèsuperscript‚Ñùùëë1ùëë2x=\begin{bmatrix}w,b\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{d+1},\>d=2, represents the vector that defines the classifier. That is, the classifier based on vector x=[w,b]ùë•matrixùë§ùëèx=\begin{bmatrix}w,b\end{bmatrix} takes a feature vector a‚àà‚Ñù2ùëésuperscript‚Ñù2a\in\mathbb{R}^{2} as input and predicts its label as ‚Ñì=sign‚Äã(‚ü®w,a‚ü©‚àíb)‚Ñìsignùë§ùëéùëè\ell=\text{sign}(\langle w,a\rangle-b). Throughout the experiments, we set the parameter c=10‚àí3ùëêsuperscript103c=10^{-3}, in order to put more weight on the classification performance of the method.

We compare the proposed formulation (3) with the alternatives in (1), (2) and (4), referred to here as the global model, local models, and squared penalty, respectively. Formulation (1) corresponds to a standard, non-personalized FL solution. That is, the classifier vectors xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}‚Äôs with (1) are equal for all users, i.e., xi=y‚àósubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptùë¶x_{i}=y^{*}, where we recall that y‚àósuperscriptùë¶y^{*} is the solution to (1). With formulation (2), each user iùëñi‚Äôs classifier vector equals xi=yi‚àó=arg‚Äãmin‚Å°fi‚Äã(x)subscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëñargminsubscriptùëìùëñùë•x_{i}=y_{i}^{*}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}f_{i}(x). In addition, we compare the proposed formulation (3) with an oracle model that knows beforehand the clustering structure of the users; then, for each user iùëñi within a cluster Cksubscriptùê∂ùëòC_{k}, the oracle lets user iùëñi‚Äôs classifier vector be xi=arg‚Äãminx‚Äã‚àëj‚ààCkfk‚Äã(x)subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptargminùë•subscriptùëósubscriptùê∂ùëòsubscriptùëìùëòùë•x_{i}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{x}\sum_{j\in C_{k}}f_{k}(x) We expect that the oracle model performs best in the considered setup among all methods, as it has an unfair advantage of knowing the cluster structure beforehand, and the data distributions of different clusters are very different, so data from a different cluster confuses another cluster‚Äôs classifier. To evaluate solutions (1)-(4), we used CVXPY [20], [21].

In order to evaluate generalization and personalization abilities of different methods, we evaluate testing accuracy of the corresponding classifiers with respect to a newly generated test data. More precisely, let xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} be a classifier vector for user iùëñi obtained through training via any of the methods (1)-(4). For each user iùëñi, we then evaluate the testing accuracy of the classifier xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} with respect to the full testing data set for the cluster to which user iùëñi belongs to. We then average the testing accuracy across all users i=1,‚Ä¶,Nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi=1,\ldots,N. For each cluster, the testing data is generated by drawing new samples (new with respect to training data) from the same distributions according to which the training data is generated. Methods (3) or (4) then exhibit generalization if the average testing accuracy is above the average testing accuracy of local models; they exhibit personalization if their average testing accuracy is above that of the global model. The performance of the models, for different values of ŒªùúÜ\lambda, is presented in Figure 2. Additionally, we present the average Euclidean distance between the classifier vectors xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}‚Äôs belonging to the same cluster. The results are summarized in Figure 3.

Figures 2 and 3 show the following. For ŒªùúÜ\lambda sufficiently large, our method enforces consensus, and effectively performs as the standard FL method (1). For ŒªùúÜ\lambda sufficiently small, the proposed method achieves both personalization, as it significantly outperforms the global model, as well as generalization, as the performance on the the complete cluster data is better than the strictly local models. Compared to the squared penalty model (4), we note that our method recovers the global model for sufficiently large ŒªùúÜ\lambda, while the squared penalty method can recover the global model only asymptotically, as ŒªùúÜ\lambda tends to infinity. The highest average accuracy is achieved by our method, being at 86.8%percent86.886.8\%, compared to the highest average accuracy of the squared penalty method, being at 86.6%percent86.686.6\%. Figure 3 shows that our method constantly produces more compact clusters, i.e. the average distance between solutions within clusters is constantly smaller than the one produced by the squared penalty method ‚Ä†‚Ä†Note that the considered simulation setup is such that the inter cluster generalization does not help. That is, data distributions across different clusters are so far apart, that the oracle, that ignores the data from other clusters, works best. Clearly, if the data distributions across different clusters are very close, another oracle that exploits inter-cluster generalization may be considered. Consider the extreme case when the data distributions across the three clusters are mutually (almost) equal, i.e., the distribution difference is negligible, but this is not known beforehand. Then, clearly, the global model (1) becomes best-performing and an ‚Äùoracle‚Äù model, in the sense that it implicitly utilizes the unknown cluster structure. Our formulation (3) can uncover this and actually match the global model for ŒªùúÜ\lambda above a threshold, and hence perform optimally. On the other hand, (4) gets closer to the global model as ŒªùúÜ\lambda increases, but never matches it. This illustration presents a scenario when there is clear merit in across-cluster generalization that the proposed formulation (3) is able to harness..

Hence, we can see that the proposed formulation (3) achieves a comparable or slightly better peak accuracy with respect to (4), while producing more compact models, i.e., significantly reducing the number of distinct models that need to be kept in the overall FL system. We report that the proposed model (3) exactly recovers the cluster structure (produces equal user models within clusters and finds 3 clusters) for Œª‚àà(0.0892,0.0919)ùúÜ0.08920.0919\lambda\in(0.0892,0.0919).

Finally, we evaluated the performance of PDMM for solving (3). This result, as well as some additional numerical simulations, can be found in Appendix C.

VI Conclusion

We proposed a novel approach to personalized federated learning that, in addition to personalization and generalization, allows for clustering of users‚Äô local models. The approach is based on a novel formulation of personalized FL wherein we minimize the sum of local users‚Äô costs with respect to their local models, subject to a penalization term that penalizes the local models‚Äô differences via a sum-of-norms penalty. We prove exact cluster recovery guarantees for a general class of local users‚Äô costs, assuming that the penalty parameter¬†ŒªùúÜ\lambda that weighs the sum-of-norms penalty falls within an appropriately defined range. We further explicitly characterize this range in terms of within-clusters and across-clusters heterogeneity of local users‚Äô costs (models). As an interesting byproduct, these results represent a direct generalization of convex clustering recovery guarantees for more general per-data point losses. Next, we propose an efficient algorithm based on the Parallel Direction Method of Multipliers (PDMM) to solve the proposed formulation in a federated server-users setting. Numerical experiments illustrate and corroborate the results.

Remark 4.

Note that, if Œª¬Ø<Œª¬Ø¬ØùúÜ¬ØùúÜ\underline{\lambda}<\overline{\lambda}, then, for any Œª‚àà(Œª¬Ø,Œª¬Ø)ùúÜ¬ØùúÜ¬ØùúÜ\lambda\in(\underline{\lambda},\overline{\lambda}), both Theorems 1 and 2 hold, i.e., formulation (3) perfectly recovers the fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i}‚Äôs cluster structure C1,‚Ä¶,CKsubscriptùê∂1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∂ùêæC_{1},\ldots,C_{K}, and moreover the models wk‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëò‚ãÜw_{k}^{\star}‚Äôs, k=1,‚Ä¶,Kùëò1‚Ä¶ùêæk=1,\ldots,K, that correspond to different clusters, are mutually distinct. Intuitively, condition Œª¬Ø<Œª¬Ø¬ØùúÜ¬ØùúÜ\underline{\lambda}<\overline{\lambda} requires that the (appropriately scaled) within-clusters function heterogeneity is smaller than the (appropriately scaled) between-clusters function heterogeneity.

In practice, we may not know quantities Œª¬Ø¬ØùúÜ\underline{\lambda} and Œª¬Ø¬ØùúÜ\overline{\lambda}. Similarly to convex clustering approaches, e.g. [22], we can solve¬†(3) for a set of values of the penalty parameter ŒªùúÜ\lambda, {Œª(r)}superscriptùúÜùëü\{\lambda^{(r)}\}, r=1,‚Ä¶,Rùëü1‚Ä¶ùëÖr=1,\ldots,R, i.e., we can generate a solution path. In more detail, we can set Œª(r+1)=c‚ÄãŒª(r)superscriptùúÜùëü1ùëêsuperscriptùúÜùëü\lambda^{(r+1)}=c\,\lambda^{(r)}, r=1,2,‚Ä¶,ùëü12‚Ä¶r=1,2,\ldots, for a small positive Œª(1)superscriptùúÜ1\lambda^{(1)}, where c>1ùëê1c>1 is a constant, and RùëÖR is the smallest index rùëür such that the number of distinct vectors xi‚ãÜ‚Äã(Œª(R))superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜsuperscriptùúÜùëÖx_{i}^{\star}(\lambda^{(R)}), i=1,‚Ä¶,Nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi=1,\ldots,N, is one.‚Ä†‚Ä†Note that we know that, for Œª‚â•Œª^ùúÜ^ùúÜ\lambda\geq\widehat{\lambda}, for some Œª^>0^ùúÜ0\widehat{\lambda}>0, all the xi‚ãÜ‚Äã(Œª)superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜùúÜx_{i}^{\star}(\lambda)‚Äôs coincide¬†[17]. Hence, all the xi‚ãÜ‚Äã(Œª)superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜùúÜx_{i}^{\star}(\lambda)‚Äôs are necessarily mutually equal for a certain Œª(R)superscriptùúÜùëÖ\lambda^{(R)}, for some finite¬†R>0ùëÖ0R>0. When solving¬†(3) for Œª=Œª(r+1)ùúÜsuperscriptùúÜùëü1\lambda=\lambda^{(r+1)}, the numerical solver of¬†(3) (e.g., see ahead Algorithm¬†1) can use warm start, i.e., it can be initialized with {xi‚ãÜ‚Äã(Œª(r))}superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜsuperscriptùúÜùëü\{x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda^{(r)})\}. The resulting solution path {xi‚ãÜ‚Äã(Œª(r))}superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜsuperscriptùúÜùëü\{x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda^{(r)})\}, r=1,‚Ä¶,Rùëü1‚Ä¶ùëÖr=1,\ldots,R, will typically have a non-increasing number of mutually distinct models xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}‚Äôs, with NùëÅN distinct models for Œª(1)superscriptùúÜ1\lambda^{(1)} and a sufficiently small Œª(1)superscriptùúÜ1\lambda^{(1)}, and one distinct model for¬†Œª(R)superscriptùúÜùëÖ\lambda^{(R)}.

If, for a certain value rùëür (or for a range of values rùëür), we have that Œª(r)‚àà(Œª¬Ø,Œª¬Ø)superscriptùúÜùëü¬ØùúÜ¬ØùúÜ\lambda^{(r)}\in(\underline{\lambda},\overline{\lambda}) and there holds Œª¬Ø<Œª¬Ø¬ØùúÜ¬ØùúÜ\underline{\lambda}<\overline{\lambda} (a hidden cluster structure exists), then solution {xi‚ãÜ‚Äã(Œª(r))}superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜsuperscriptùúÜùëü\{x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda^{(r)})\} satisfies Theorems 1 and 2, i.e., the hidden cluster structure is uncovered. For a fixed Œª(r)superscriptùúÜùëü\lambda^{(r)}, we can check whether the hidden cluster structure is uncovered in an ‚Äúa posteriori‚Äù way as follows. We first fix the clustering C1=C1‚Äã(Œª(r)),‚Ä¶,CK=CK‚Äã(Œª(r))formulae-sequencesubscriptùê∂1subscriptùê∂1superscriptùúÜùëü‚Ä¶subscriptùê∂ùêæsubscriptùê∂ùêæsuperscriptùúÜùëüC_{1}=C_{1}(\lambda^{(r)}),\ldots,C_{K}=C_{K}(\lambda^{(r)}) induced by {xi‚ãÜ‚Äã(Œª(r))}superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜsuperscriptùúÜùëü\{x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda^{(r)})\}, and then we check whether conditions¬†(25) and (26) hold.

Even when we are not directly concerned with uncovering the hidden cluster structure in the sense of Theorems¬†1 and 2, there are several merits of computing the solution path, similarly to the convex clustering scenario, e.g.,¬†[22]. For example, depending on the requirements of a given application, we can select the index rùëür, i.e., the model {xi‚ãÜ‚Äã(Œª(r))}superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜsuperscriptùúÜùëü\{x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda^{(r)})\} for which the number of distinct xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}‚Äôs (closely) matches the need of the current application. Furthermore, increasing ŒªùúÜ\lambda translates into improving the degree of generalization and reducing the degree of personalization, so one can select the appropriate {xi‚ãÜ‚Äã(Œª(r))}superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜsuperscriptùúÜùëü\{x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda^{(r)})\} according to the current application needs.

Appendix B Further insights through a special case

In this section, we provide further insight into the method, by analyzing a special case. We consider an explicit clustering structure, given by the following assumption.

Assumption 3.

There exists a node partition C1,C2,‚Ä¶,CK,subscriptùê∂1subscriptùê∂2‚Ä¶subscriptùê∂ùêæC_{1},C_{2},\ldots,C_{K}, and parameters œµk,Œ¥k‚Äãl>0,k,l=1,‚Ä¶,K,k‚â†l,formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-œµùëòsubscriptùõøùëòùëô0ùëòùëô1‚Ä¶ùêæùëòùëô\epsilon_{k},\delta_{kl}>0,\>k,l=1,\ldots,K,\>k\neq l, such that the following holds:

(28)

We then have the following result.

Theorem 3.

Let Assumptions 1, 2 and 3 hold. Then, for any ŒªùúÜ\lambda satisfying

Œª‚àà[maxk‚àà[K]‚Å°œµknk,mink‚â†l‚Å°[Œ¥k‚Äãl‚àí(œµk+œµl)]2‚Äãmaxk‚àà[K]‚Äã‚àël‚â†knl],ùúÜsubscriptùëòdelimited-[]ùêæsubscriptitalic-œµùëòsubscriptùëõùëòsubscriptùëòùëôsubscriptùõøùëòùëôsubscriptitalic-œµùëòsubscriptitalic-œµùëô2subscriptùëòdelimited-[]ùêæsubscriptùëôùëòsubscriptùëõùëô\lambda\in\bigg{[}\max_{k\in[K]}\frac{\epsilon_{k}}{n_{k}},\frac{\min_{k\neq l}\big{[}\delta_{kl}-(\epsilon_{k}+\epsilon_{l})\big{]}}{2\max_{k\in[K]}\sum_{l\neq k}n_{l}}\bigg{]}, (29)

the conditions of Theorems 1 and 2 are satisfied.

Remark 5.

Note that conditions (27) and (28) can be interpreted as measures of within-cluster homogeneity and between-cluster heterogeneity, respectively. In particular, let xi‚Ä†‚àà‚Ñùdsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†superscript‚Ñùùëëx_{i}^{\dagger}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} denote a optima of fi‚Äã(x),i‚àà[N]subscriptùëìùëñùë•ùëñdelimited-[]ùëÅf_{i}(x),\>i\in[N]. Then, per (27) and (28), we have

‚Äñ‚àáfj‚Äã(xi‚Ä†)‚Äñ‚â§œµk,‚àÄi,j‚ààCk,formulae-sequencenorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†subscriptitalic-œµùëòfor-allùëñùëósubscriptùê∂ùëò\displaystyle\|\nabla f_{j}(x_{i}^{\dagger})\|\leq\epsilon_{k},\forall i,j\in C_{k},
‚Äñ‚àáfj‚Äã(xi‚Ä†)‚Äñ‚â•Œ¥k‚Äãl,‚àÄi‚ààCk,‚àÄj‚ààCl,k‚â†l.formulae-sequencenorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†subscriptùõøùëòùëôformulae-sequencefor-allùëñsubscriptùê∂ùëòformulae-sequencefor-allùëósubscriptùê∂ùëôùëòùëô\displaystyle\|\nabla f_{j}(x_{i}^{\dagger})\|\geq\delta_{kl},\forall i\in C_{k},\forall j\in C_{l},k\neq l.

From convexity of fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i}‚Äôs (Assumption 1) for any k‚àà[K],i,j‚ààCkformulae-sequenceùëòdelimited-[]ùêæùëñùëósubscriptùê∂ùëòk\in[K],\>i,j\in C_{k}, if œµksubscriptitalic-œµùëò\epsilon_{k} small, we can expect fj‚Äã(xi‚Ä†)subscriptùëìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†f_{j}(x_{i}^{\dagger}) to be a good approximation to fj‚Äã(xj‚Ä†)subscriptùëìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚Ä†f_{j}(x_{j}^{\dagger}). Hence, for Œ¥k‚Äãlsubscriptùõøùëòùëô\delta_{kl} large, fj‚Äã(xi‚Ä†)subscriptùëìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†f_{j}(x_{i}^{\dagger}) can be an arbitrarily bad approximation to fj‚Äã(xj‚Ä†)subscriptùëìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚Ä†f_{j}(x_{j}^{\dagger}). Therefore, œµksubscriptitalic-œµùëò\epsilon_{k} and Œ¥k‚Äãlsubscriptùõøùëòùëô\delta_{kl} can be interpreted as natural measures of within-cluster homogeneity and between-cluster heterogeneity, respectively.

Remark 6.

Theorem 3 states that the clustering structure of the solution is maintained, for any choice of ŒªùúÜ\lambda satisfying (29). Compared to the results from Theorems 1 and 2, the resulting interval (if existent) is smaller, but the lower and upper bounds are independent of ŒªùúÜ\lambda, and of the optimal solutions of problem (5).

Remark 7.

Compared with (25) and (26), while possibly smaller, the interval (29) provides a more natural interpretation: if the between-cluster heterogeneity is sufficiently larger than the within-cluster homogeneity, so the interval (29) is non-empty, a (strong) clustering structure among users exists, and can be recovered by (3).

We now prove Theorem 3.

Proof.

Moreover, assuming strong convexity, Assumption 3 implies a clustering structure among the local solutions, as shown by the following result.

Theorem 4.

Let each fi‚Äã(x),i=1,‚Ä¶,N,formulae-sequencesubscriptùëìùëñùë•ùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅf_{i}(x),\>i=1,\ldots,N, be Œºùúá\mu-strongly convex, and let Assumptions 2, 3 hold. Denote by xi‚Ä†superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†x_{i}^{\dagger} the (global) optima of fi‚Äã(x),i=1,‚Ä¶,Nformulae-sequencesubscriptùëìùëñùë•ùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅf_{i}(x),\>i=1,\ldots,N. Then, the following holds:

‚Äñxi‚Ä†‚àíxj‚Ä†‚Äñnormsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚Ä†\displaystyle\|x_{i}^{\dagger}-x_{j}^{\dagger}\| ‚â§œµkŒº,‚àÄi,j‚ààCk,formulae-sequenceabsentsubscriptitalic-œµùëòùúáfor-allùëñùëósubscriptùê∂ùëò\displaystyle\leq\frac{\epsilon_{k}}{\mu},\forall i,j\in C_{k}, (30)
‚Äñxi‚Ä†‚àíxj‚Ä†‚Äñnormsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚Ä†\displaystyle\|x_{i}^{\dagger}-x_{j}^{\dagger}\| ‚â•Œ¥k‚ÄãlL,‚àÄi‚ààCk,‚àÄj‚ààCl,k‚â†l.formulae-sequenceabsentsubscriptùõøùëòùëôùêøformulae-sequencefor-allùëñsubscriptùê∂ùëòformulae-sequencefor-allùëósubscriptùê∂ùëôùëòùëô\displaystyle\geq\frac{\delta_{kl}}{L},\forall i\in C_{k},\>\forall j\in C_{l},\>k\neq l. (31)
Remark 8.

Theorem 4 shows that optimal models of users belonging to the same clusters are at least œµ~~italic-œµ\tilde{\epsilon} close, with optimal models of users belonging to different clusters being at least Œ¥~~ùõø\tilde{\delta} apart. Here, œµ~=maxk‚àà[K]‚Å°œµkŒº~italic-œµsubscriptùëòdelimited-[]ùêæsubscriptitalic-œµùëòùúá\tilde{\epsilon}=\max_{k\in[K]}\frac{\epsilon_{k}}{\mu}, and Œ¥~=mink‚â†l‚Å°Œ¥k‚ÄãlL~ùõøsubscriptùëòùëôsubscriptùõøùëòùëôùêø\tilde{\delta}=\min_{k\neq l}\frac{\delta_{kl}}{L}. In the case that œµ~<Œ¥~~italic-œµ~ùõø\tilde{\epsilon}<\tilde{\delta}, the clustering structure implied by Theorem 4 is strong, in the sense that the local optima corresponding to different clusters are well separated.

Remark 9.

In the case that œµ~<Œ¥~~italic-œµ~ùõø\tilde{\epsilon}<\tilde{\delta} and the interval given by (29) is non-empty, Theorems 3 and 4 show that a natural clustering structure among the user‚Äôs costs exists. In addition, the proposed formulation (3) uncovers the said structure, for any ŒªùúÜ\lambda in a range that is independent of the optimal solutions of problem (5).

We now prove Theorem 4

Proof.

From Assumption 3, for i‚ààCkùëñsubscriptùê∂ùëòi\in C_{k}, j‚ààClùëósubscriptùê∂ùëôj\in C_{l}, k‚â†lùëòùëôk\neq l, and for all x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, we have

Œ¥k‚Äãl‚â§‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(x)‚àí‚àáfj‚Äã(x)‚Äñ.subscriptùõøùëòùëônorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë•‚àásubscriptùëìùëóùë•\displaystyle\delta_{kl}\leq\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{j}(x)\|.

In particular, for x=xi‚Ä†ùë•superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†x=x_{i}^{\dagger}, we have

Œ¥k‚Äãl‚â§‚Äñ‚àáfj‚Äã(xi‚Ä†)‚Äñ=‚Äñ‚àáfj‚Äã(xi‚Ä†)‚àí‚àáfj‚Äã(xj‚Ä†)‚Äñ‚â§L‚Äã‚Äñxi‚Ä†‚àíxj‚Ä†‚Äñ,subscriptùõøùëòùëônorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†norm‚àásubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†‚àásubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚Ä†ùêønormsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚Ä†\displaystyle\delta_{kl}\leq\|\nabla f_{j}(x_{i}^{\dagger})\|=\|\nabla f_{j}(x_{i}^{\dagger})-\nabla f_{j}(x_{j}^{\dagger})\|\leq L\|x_{i}^{\dagger}-x_{j}^{\dagger}\|,

implying (31). Similarly, for i,j‚ààCkùëñùëósubscriptùê∂ùëòi,j\in C_{k}, and for all x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, we have

‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(x)‚àí‚àáfj‚Äã(x)‚Äñ‚â§œµk.norm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë•‚àásubscriptùëìùëóùë•subscriptitalic-œµùëò\displaystyle\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{j}(x)\|\leq\epsilon_{k}.

In particular, for x=xi‚Ä†ùë•superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†x=x_{i}^{\dagger}, we have

œµk2‚â•‚Äñ‚àáfj‚Äã(xi‚Ä†)‚Äñ2‚â•2‚ÄãŒº‚Äã(fj‚Äã(xi‚Ä†)‚àífj‚Äã(xj‚Ä†)),superscriptsubscriptitalic-œµùëò2superscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†22ùúásubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†subscriptùëìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚Ä†\displaystyle\epsilon_{k}^{2}\geq\|\nabla f_{j}(x_{i}^{\dagger})\|^{2}\geq 2\mu(f_{j}(x_{i}^{\dagger})-f_{j}(x_{j}^{\dagger})), (32)

where we used the Polyak-Lojasiewitz inequality in the second step. From strong convexity of fjsubscriptùëìùëóf_{j}, we have

fj‚Äã(xi‚Ä†)subscriptùëìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†\displaystyle f_{j}(x_{i}^{\dagger}) ‚â•fj‚Äã(xj‚Ä†)+Œº2‚Äã‚Äñxi‚Ä†‚àíxj‚Ä†‚Äñ2.absentsubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚Ä†ùúá2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚Ä†2\displaystyle\geq f_{j}(x_{j}^{\dagger})+\frac{\mu}{2}\|x_{i}^{\dagger}-x_{j}^{\dagger}\|^{2}.

Rearranging and plugging into (32), we get

œµk2‚â•Œº2‚Äã‚Äñxi‚Ä†‚àíxj‚Ä†‚Äñ2,superscriptsubscriptitalic-œµùëò2superscriptùúá2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä†superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚Ä†2\epsilon_{k}^{2}\geq\mu^{2}\|x_{i}^{\dagger}-x_{j}^{\dagger}\|^{2},

which implies (30). ‚àé

Appendix C Additional experiments

Here, we present some additional experiments. First, we evaluate the clustering recovery of (3) and compare it with (4). The data is generated using the same methodology described in Section V, with each ellipse containing 100100100 data points, hence each cluster contains a total of 200200200 data points. The dataset is shown in Figure 4. We generate n=10ùëõ10n=10 users per cluster, and each user samples 85%percent8585\% of points from the cluster it belongs to, ensuring the resulting models will be similar for users within clusters. The performance of (3) and (4) is evaluated for different values of the penalty parameter ŒªùúÜ\lambda, belonging to {1000,1,0.12,0.08,0.05,0.03,0.02,0.01}100010.120.080.050.030.020.01\{1000,1,0.12,0.08,0.05,0.03,0.02,0.01\}. The dashed lines in the figures correspond to optimal separators for each cluster, evaluated on the full data. The full lines represent model estimates corresponding to (3) and (4). The results are presented in Figure 6.

We can see that Figure 6 corroborates the results from Theorems 1 and 2. In particular, for ŒªùúÜ\lambda sufficiently large, our method produces only one model across all users. For ŒªùúÜ\lambda higher than, but close to the theoretical upper bound from Theorem 2, the method produces two models across all the users (second row, left image). Finally, for ŒªùúÜ\lambda within the theoretical range, our method produces exactly three models, uncovering the clustering structure. We remark that, while the produced models are not optimal for the training data, they can still be used as a guideline: if a clustering solution is obtained, and the parameter ŒªùúÜ\lambda falls within the theoretical bounds suggested by Theorems 1 and 2, an innate clustering structure is uncovered, and the users that are selected in the clusters can focus on training their models within the cluster of similar users. Moreover, the left image in the third row suggests that the bounds obtained by Theorems 1 and 2 are somewhat conservative - the proposed method produced 3 models across users, for ŒªùúÜ\lambda that is lower than the theoretical lower bound, meaning that in practice, the clustering structure can be recovered for a wider range of ŒªùúÜ\lambda than predicted by theory.

In the second experiment, we present the convergence results of PDMM for solving the proposed method in federated settings. The dataset and the parameters are the same as was described in the setting above. For PDMM in the federated settings, in each iteration we randomly select a subset of users, being 40%percent4040\% of the total users. The PDMM tuning parameters are selected as œÅ=10,Œ∑=10,œÑ=45,ŒΩ=15formulae-sequenceùúå10formulae-sequenceùúÇ10formulae-sequenceùúè45ùúà15\rho=10,\>\eta=10,\>\tau=\frac{4}{5},\>\nu=\frac{1}{5}. While this is not pursued here, we remark that it is possible to reduce Algorithm¬†1 complexity by dynamically (over iterations) exploiting the clustered structure of a solution to¬†(3). Namely, note that, for a solution {xi‚ãÜ}superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜ\{x_{i}^{\star}\} of (3), if xi‚ãÜ=xj‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚ãÜx_{i}^{\star}=x_{j}^{\star} for some i‚â†jùëñùëói\neq j, then zi‚Äãj‚ãÜ=0superscriptsubscriptùëßùëñùëó‚ãÜ0z_{ij}^{\star}=0. This may be exploited in the algorithm implementation as follows: once user iùëñi detects that zi‚Äãj(t)superscriptsubscriptùëßùëñùëóùë°z_{ij}^{(t)} is close to zero over a range of consecutive iterations, it can cease updating zi‚Äãj(t)superscriptsubscriptùëßùëñùëóùë°z_{ij}^{(t)} and cease communicating it to the server, and it can also replace locally xj(t)superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëóùë°x_{j}^{(t)} with xi(t)superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùë°x_{i}^{(t)} in its subsequent updates. This also translates into reducing the communication cost at the server side, as xj(t)superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëóùë°x_{j}^{(t)} no longer needs to be communicated to user¬†iùëñi. In this way, storage, computational, and communication costs may be dynamically reduced as the algorithm evolves.
